title: The Android-powered Boox Palma 2 Pro fits in your pocket, but itâ€™s not a phone
summary: This e-reader has a color screen and 5G.
body: Digital reading devices like the Kindle have existed for almost 20 years, and the standard eReader form factor has hardly changed at all. Amazon, Boox, and a few other companies have offered larger E Ink screens, but how about something smaller? Boox has unveiled its second-generation Palma e-reader, which still fits in your pocket but adds a color screen and mobile data connectivity. The first-gen Palma launched last year, earning fans who saw it as a way to read and access some apps without the full spate of distracting smartphone experiences. Boox e-readers are essentially Android tablets with E ink screens and a few software quirks that arise from their unofficial Google Play implementation. The second-gen Palma might offer more opportunities for distraction because itâ€™s almost a smartphone. The Palma 2 Pro upgrades the 6.1-inch monochrome display from the original to a 6.13-inch color E Ink Kaleido display. Thatâ€™s the same technology used in Amazonâ€™s Kindle Colorsoft . The Amazon reader is a bit larger with its 7-inch display and chunkier bezels. Of course, the Kindle isnâ€™t trying to fit in your pocket like the Palma 2 Pro, which is roughly the size and shape of a phone. Readâ€¦

title: Tech billionaires are now shaping the militarization of American cities
summary: Money means access to powerâ€”and tech has plenty of money.
body: Yesterday, Donald Trump announced on social media that he had been planning to â€œsurgeâ€ troops into San Francisco this weekendâ€”but was dissuaded from doing so by several tech billionaires. â€œFriends of mine who live in the area called last night to ask me not to go forward with the surge,â€ Trump wrote. Who are these â€œfriendsâ€? Trump named â€œgreat people like [Nvidia CEO] Jensen Huang, [Salesforce CEO] Marc Benioff, and othersâ€ who told him that â€œthe future of San Francisco is great. They want to give it a â€˜shot.â€™ Therefore, we will not surge San Francisco on Saturday. Stay tuned!â€ Read full article Comments

title: Teslaâ€™s â€œMad Maxâ€ mode is now under federal scrutiny
summary: The new mode added in the latest update will speed and weave through traffic.
body: Earlier this month, Tesla rolled out a new firmware update that added a pair of new driving modes for the controversial full self-driving (FSD) feature. One, called â€œSloth,â€ relaxes acceleration and stays in its lane. The other, called â€œMad Max,â€ does the opposite: It speeds and swerves through traffic to get you to your destination faster. And after multiple reports of FSD Teslas doing just that, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration wants to know more. In fact, â€œMad Maxâ€ mode is not entirely newâ€”Tesla beta-tested the same feature in Autopilot in 2018, before deciding not to roll it out in a production release after widespread outcry. These days, the company is evidently feeling less constrained; despite having just lost a federal wrongful death lawsuit that will cost it hundreds of millions of dollars , it described the new mode as being able to drive â€œthrough traffic at an incredible pace, all while still being super smooth. It drives your car like a sports car. If you are running late, this is the mode for you.â€ Read full article Comments

title: EU accuses Meta of violating content rules in move that could anger Trump
summary: EU alleges Facebook and Instagram make it too hard to report illegal content.
body: Meta violated the Digital Services Act (DSA) by failing to give Facebook and Instagram users simple mechanisms to report illegal content, the European Commission said in a preliminary decision announced yesterday. Meta also failed to give users an effective way to challenge content moderation decisions, the EC said. â€œWhen it comes to Meta, neither Facebook nor Instagram appear to provide a user-friendly and easily accessible â€˜Notice and Actionâ€™ mechanism for users to flag illegal content, such as child sexual abuse material and terrorist content,â€ the EC press release said. The EC said that Meta mechanisms seem to â€œimpose several unnecessary steps and additional demands on users. In addition, both Facebook and Instagram appear to use so-called â€˜dark patterns,â€™ or deceptive interface designs, when it comes to the â€˜Notice and Actionâ€™ mechanisms.â€ The EC also found that the content moderation appeal mechanisms used by Facebook and Instagram do not â€œallow users to provide explanations or supporting evidence to substantiate their appeals. This makes it difficult for users in the EU to further explain why they disagree with Metaâ€™s content decision, limiting the effectiveness of the appeâ€¦

title: Rivian agrees to settle shareholder lawsuit for $250 million
summary: Rivian has agreed to settle a 2022 shareholder lawsuit. The automaker will pay out $250 million to qualifying investors if the agreement is approved. The lawsuit stemmed from alleged deception surrounding a March 2022 price hike for the R1S SUV and R1T truck. The class-action lawsuit alleges that Râ€¦

title: Microsoftâ€™s Mico heightens the risks of parasocial LLM relationships
summary: "It looks like you're trying to find a friend. Would you like help?"
body: Microsoft is rolling out a new face for its AI, and its name is Mico. The company announced the new, animated blob-like avatar for Copilotâ€™s voice mode yesterday as part of a â€œhuman-centeredâ€ rebranding of Microsoftâ€™s Copilot AI efforts. Mico is part of a Microsoft program dedicated to the idea that â€œtechnology should work in service of people,â€ Microsoft wrote. The company insists this effort is â€œnot [about] chasing engagement or optimizing for screen time. Weâ€™re building AI that gets you back to your life. That deepens human connection.â€ Mico has drawn instant and obvious comparisons to Clippy , the animated paperclip that popped up to offer help with Microsoft Office starting in the â€™90s . Microsoft has leaned into this comparison with an Easter egg that can transform Mico into an animated Clippy . Read full article Comments

title: Rivian is settling $250 million lawsuit to focus on next yearâ€™s R2 EV
summary: Investors sued Rivian claiming it knew prices had to rise after its IPO.
body: Electric vehicle startup Rivian announced on Thursday that it has settled a lawsuit with some of its investors. The company continues to deny allegations of making â€œmaterially untrueâ€ statements during its inial public offering but says it agreed to pay $250 million to clear itself of distractions as it focuses on building its next EV, the mass-market R2 , which is due next year. Rivian was first sued by a shareholder in 2022 over claims that the startup knew it would cost far more for it to build each R1T electric truck and R1S electric SUV than the advertised $67,500 and $70,000 prices, respectively. A big surprise price increase would tarnish the nascent automakerâ€™s reputation, the lawsuit claimed, and could lead to many of the almost 56,000 pre-orders being canceled. Just a few months after its November 2021 IPO, the company had indeed issued a hefty price hike : $79,500 for the R1T and $84,500 for the R1S SUV. After an outcry, the company said it would honor the original price for its existing preorders. By that point, though, the damage was done, and more than a third of the companyâ€™s value was erased within a few days, the lawsuit alleged. Read full article Comments

title: Bats eat the birds they pluck from the sky while on the wing
summary: A handful of bat species hunt birds, and new sensor data tells us how.
body: There are three species of bats that eat birds. We know that because we have found feathers and other avian remains in their feces. What we didnâ€™t know was how exactly they hunt birds, which are quite a bit heavier, faster, and stronger than the insects bats usually dine on. To find out, Elena Tena, a biologist at DoÃ±ana Biological Station in Seville, Spain, and her colleagues attached ultra-light sensors to Nyctalus Iasiopterus , the largest bats in Europe. What they found was jaw-droppingly brutal. Inconspicuous interceptors Nyctalus Iasiopterus , otherwise known as greater noctule bats, have a wingspan of about 45 centimeters. They have reddish-brown or chestnut fur with a slightly paler underside, and usually weigh around 40 to 60 grams. Despite that minimal weight, they are the largest of the three bat species known to eat birds, so the key challenge in getting a glimpse into the way they hunt was finding sensors light enough to not impede the batsâ€™ flight. Read full article Comments

title: This browser claims â€œperfect privacies protection,â€ but it acts like malware
summary: Researchers note links to Asiaâ€™s booming cybercrime and illegal gambling networks.
body: The Universe Browser makes some big promises to its potential users. Its online advertisements claim itâ€™s the â€œfastest browser,â€ that people using it will â€œavoid privacy leaksâ€ and that the software will help â€œkeep you away from danger.â€ However, everything likely isnâ€™t as it seems. The browser, which is linked to Chinese online gambling websites and is thought to have been downloaded millions of times, actually routes all Internet traffic through servers in China and â€œcovertly installs several programs that run silently in the background,â€ according to new findings from network security company Infoblox. The researchers say the â€œhiddenâ€ elements include features similar to malwareâ€”including â€œkey logging, surreptitious connections,â€ and changing a deviceâ€™s network connections. Perhaps most significantly, the Infoblox researchers who collaborated with the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) on the work, found links between the browserâ€™s operation and Southeast Asiaâ€™s sprawling, multibillion-dollar cybercrime ecosystem , which has connections to money-laundering, illegal online gambling, human trafficking, and scam operations that use forced labor . The browser itself, â€¦

title: Rocket Report: China tests Falcon 9 lookalike; NASAâ€™s Moon rocket fully stacked

body: Welcome to Edition 8.16 of the Rocket Report! The 10th anniversary of SpaceXâ€™s first Falcon 9 rocket landing is coming up at the end of this year. Weâ€™re still waiting for a second company to bring back an orbital-class booster from space for a propulsive landing. Two companies, Jeff Bezosâ€™ Blue Origin and Chinaâ€™s LandSpace, could join SpaceXâ€™s exclusive club as soon as next month. (Bezos might claim heâ€™s already part of the club , but thereâ€™s a distinction to be made.) Each company is in the final stages of launch preparations â€”Blue Origin for its second New Glenn rocket, and LandSpace for the debut flight of its Zhuque-3 rocket. Blue Origin and LandSpace will both attempt to land their first stage boosters downrange from their launch sites. Theyâ€™re not exactly in a race with one another, but it will be fascinating to see how New Glenn and Zhuque-3 perform during the uphill and downhill phases of flight, and whether one or both of the new rockets stick the landing. As always, we welcome reader submissions . If you donâ€™t want to miss an issue, please subscribe using the box below (the form will not appear on AMP-enabled versions of the site). body: OpenAI has acquired Software Applications Incorporated (SAI), perhaps best known for the core team that produced what became Shortcuts on Apple platforms. More recently, the team has been working on Sky, a context-aware AI interface layer on top of macOS. The financial terms of the acquisition have not been publicly disclosed. â€œAI progress isnâ€™t only about advancing intelligenceâ€”itâ€™s about unlocking it through interfaces that understand context, adapt to your intent, and work seamlessly,â€ an OpenAI rep wrote in the companyâ€™s blog post about the acquisition. The post goes on to specify that OpenAI plans to â€œbring Skyâ€™s deep macOS integration and product craft into ChatGPT, and all members of the team will join OpenAI.â€ That includes SAI co-founders Ari Weinstein (CEO), Conrad Kramer (CTO), and Kim Beverett (Product Lead)â€”all of whom worked together for several years at Apple after Apple acquired Weinstein and Kramerâ€™s previous company, which produced an automation tool called Workflows, to integrate Shortcuts across Appleâ€™s software platforms. Reddit alleged that Perplexity feeds off Reddit and Google, claiming to be â€œthe worldâ€™s first answer engineâ€ but really doing â€œnothing groundbreaking.â€ â€œIts answer engine simply uses a different companyâ€™sâ€ large language model â€œto parse through a massive number of Google search results to see if it can answer a userâ€™s question based on those results,â€ the lawsuit said. â€œBut Perplexity can only run its â€˜answer engineâ€™ by wrongfully accessing and scraping Reddit content appearing in Googleâ€™s own search results from Googleâ€™s own search engine.â€ Read full article Comments

title: Researchers show that training on â€œjunk dataâ€ can lead to LLM â€œbrain rotâ€
summary: Models trained on short, popular, and/or "superficial" tweets perform worse on benchmarks.
body: On the surface, it seems obvious that training an LLM with â€œhigh qualityâ€ data will lead to better performance than feeding it any old â€œlow qualityâ€ junk you can find. Now, a group of researchers is attempting to quantify just how much this kind of low quality data can cause an LLM to experience effects akin to human â€œbrain rot.â€ For a pre-print paper published this month , the researchers from Texas A&M, the University of Texas, and Purdue University drew inspiration from existing research showing how humans who consume â€œlarge volumes of trivial and unchallenging online contentâ€ can develop problems with attention, memory, and social cognition. That led them to what theyâ€™re calling the â€œLLM brain rot hypothesis,â€ summed up as the idea that â€œcontinual pre-training on junk web text induces lasting cognitive decline in LLMs.â€ Figuring out what counts as â€œjunk web textâ€ and what counts as â€œquality contentâ€ is far from a simple or fully objective process, of course. But the researchers used a few different metrics to tease a â€œjunk datasetâ€ and â€œcontrol datasetâ€ from HuggingFaceâ€™s corpus of 100 million tweets . Read full article Comments

title: Dinosaurs may have flourished right up to when the asteroid hit
summary: Fossil beds in New Mexico show diverse species present in the late Cretaceous.
body: The end of the dinosaurs was clearly linked to an asteroid impact that brought the Cretaceous period to a close. But the details of their end have remained a matter of debate since the impact crater was discovered. There is a lot of evidence that the impact alone should have been enough to do them in . But the asteroid arrived amid major volcanic eruptions associated with previous mass extinctions. And fossils dating to just before the impact have suggested that dinosaur-dominated ecosystems had become less diverse, making them more prone to collapse. Now, a new study has revealed that fossils we already know about originated within the last few hundred thousand years before the impact that killed off all dinosaurs except birds. The results indicate that species richness wasnâ€™t likely to be a problemâ€”at least in the neighborhood of the impact itself. Wyoming vs. New Mexico Most of what we know about the last days of the non-avian dinosaurs comes from the Hell Creek Formation, rich fossil beds in present-day Wyoming. These not only date from within a few hundred thousand years prior to the impact, but there may be deposits that capture the immediate aftermath of the impact. Beyond â€¦

Meanwhile, the person replacing him as director is a close friend of Vice President JD Vance and was installed in a process that experts describe as completely outside standard hiring practices. The series of eventsâ€”revealed in an email to staff last week from the National Institutes of Health Director Jay Bhattacharyaâ€”is only exacerbating the spiraling fears that science is being deeply corrupted by politics under the Trump administration. Richard Woychik, a molecular geneticist, is the outgoing director of the NIHâ€™s National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS), which is located in Research Triangle Park, North Carolina. He has been director since 2020 and was recently appointed to a second five-year term, according to Science magazine . Woychik was hired at the institute in 2010, when he joined as deputy director, and was appointed acting director in 2019. Read full article Comments

body: Microsoft said earlier this month that it wanted to add better voice controls to Copilot , Windows 11â€™s built-in chatbot-slash-virtual assistant. As described, this new version of Copilot sounds an awful lot like another stab at Cortana, the voice assistant that Microsoft tried (and failed) to get people to use in Windows 10 in the mid-to-late 2010s. Turns out that the company isnâ€™t done trying to reformulate and revive ideas it has already tried before. As part of a push toward what it calls â€œhuman-centered AI,â€ Microsoft is now putting a face on Copilot . Literally, a face: â€œMicoâ€ is an â€œexpressive, customizable, and warmâ€ blob with a face that dynamically â€œlistens, reacts, and even changes colors to reflect your interactionsâ€ as you interact with Copilot. (Another important adjective for Mico: â€œoptional.â€) Mico (rhymes with â€œpicoâ€) recalls old digital assistants like Clippy, Microsoft Bob, and Rover , ideas that Microsoft tried in the â€™90s and early 2000s before mostly abandoning them. title: The first people to set foot in Australia were fossil hunters
summary: Europeans weren't the first people to collect fossils in Australia.
body: Australiaâ€™s First Peoples may or may not have hunted the continentâ€™s megafauna to extinction, but they definitely collected fossils. A team of archaeologists examined the fossilized leg bone of an extinct kangaroo and realized that instead of evidence of butchery, cut marks on the bone reveal an ancient attempt at fossil collecting. That leaves Australia with little evidence of First Peoples hunting or butchering the continentâ€™s extinct megafaunaâ€”and reopens the question of whether humans were responsible for the die-off of that continentâ€™s giant Ice Age marsupials. Fossil hunting in the Ice Age In the unsolved case of whether humans hunted Australiaâ€™s Ice Age megafauna to extinction, the key piece of evidence so far is a tibia (one of the bones of the lower leg) from an extinct short-faced kangaroo. Instead of hopping like their modern relatives, these extinct kangaroos walked on their hind legs, probably placing all their weight on the tips of single hoofed toes. This particular kangaroo wasnâ€™t quite fully grown when it died, which happened sometime between 44,500 and 55,200 years ago, based on uranium-series dating of the thin layer of rock covering most of the fossils in Mammoâ€¦

For millions of players, though, the game is more about collecting and/or buying rare in-game loot and flipping it for what can be very significant sums on the Steam Marketplace . Wednesday night, Valve sent that multi-billion-dollar market into turmoil as part of a so-called â€œsmall update.â€ Now, players can use the gameâ€™s â€œTrade Up contractsâ€ to exchange five common, â€œCovertâ€ items (also known as â€œredsâ€) for the kinds of knives and gloves that have until now been much harder to obtain. That â€œsmall updateâ€ has unsurprisingly had an immediate and sharp impact on the Marketplace price for those items. One rare knife that sold for over $14,000 less than 24 hours ago has seen its minimum price plummet over 50 percent as of this writing, according to the trackers at Pricempire. Last month, I met the 499P again as it visited the Circuit of the Americas in Austin, along with the rest of the World Endurance Championship.
